texts.shortText:
Sea fans are characterized by having a stiff inner skeleton made of a horn-like protein called gorgonin. This is covered by an often brightly-pigmented layer of living tissue from which small, retractable polyps emerge. Each polyp has 8 pinnate (feathery) tentacles.

One of the largest and most common seafans in the region and can form spectacular forests on deeper reefs. Easily identified by its thick, flattened and often spreading trunk and repeatedly branching, tree-like form, all the branches being arranged to be fan-like in a single plane. Colour cherry-red. The pale polyps can be retracted into slits in the colony, but when extended give the branches a paler, fuzzy appearance.
Colonies up to 2 m tall, branches about 10 mm wide.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic coast of Cape Peninsula to Sodwana bay.

Common on rocky reefs in depth of about 10-100 m, sometimes in extensive groups that have an almost forest like appearance. As with other larger sea fans thought to be very slow-growing and large individuals may be many decades, perhaps over a century, old.

These and other large sea fans host a variety of smaller species, such as basket stars, spider and sponge crabs, brittle stars, gastropods, etc. Cat sharks also regularly attach their egg cases to the stems.
Use the tentacles to capture small planktonic organisms from the water column.

Colonies spread by budding new polyps from the tips and broken fragments can develop into new colonies if deposited in suitable habitats. Details of sexual reproduction are unknown for this species, but other sea-fans have separate male and female colonies and release sperm and eggs into the water. These merge to form planktonic larvae which settle and grow into new colonies.

The large size and repeatedly-branching, fan-like form are fairly characteristic, but can be confused with various other large red sea fans, especially Eunicella tricoronata, which has wavy, sinuous branches and  Eunicella albicans, which has an elongate and sparsely branched colony form.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 32).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 48).

Williams, GC (1992). The Alcyonacea of southern Africa. Gorgonian octocorals (Coelenterata, Anthozoa). Annals of the South African Museum, 101(8), 181-296. (p. 239).

Williams, GC & Lindo, KG (1997). A review of the octocorallian genus Leptogorgia (Anthozoa: Gorgoniidae) in the Indian Ocean and Subantarctic, with description of a new species and comparisons with related taxa. Proceedings of the California Academy of Sciences, 49, 499–521.
